docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Mysteries Within: A Surgeon Reflects on Medical Myths'' by Dr. Sherwin B. Nuland (Simon & Schuster, 2000). Don't take the scientist's objective observation for granted, cautions Dr. Sherwin B. Nuland in ''The Mysteries Within.'' Until the 19th century, the greatest thinkers in medicine (Hippocrates, Galen, Paracelsus) turned to supernatural powers, superstition, fanciful spirits and energies to fill the holes in their medical theories.

headline.main: Myth and Superstition in Ancient Medicine

docs.abstract: Laurie Tarkan reviews book The Mysteries Within: A Surgeon Reflects on Medical Myths by Dr Sherwin B Nuland; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last February a friend and I (both 60-ish women who walk about three miles every morning) flew to Tucson for a week of hiking. We went prepared with sunscreen, sun-blocking shirts and hats, several water bottles each and a first-aid kit in our backpacks, plus an ample supply of ibuprofen just in case. Each morning before heading for the hills we filled sealable plastic bags with orange and grapefruit sections for rest-stop refreshment. After a substantial breakfast of cereal and fruit and a vigorous morning hike of about four hours, a light lunch of soup or salad sufficed. A late afternoon swim helped to relax tense muscles and prepare us for dinners that were replete with vegetables complemented by chicken or seafood and hearty bread.

headline.main: Good Planning Makes for Great Hiking

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column offers advice on avoiding, and handling, injury and illness when hiking; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: James Pokorny sat upright in bed in his room at the University of Washington Burn Center at Harborview as a nurse prepared to unwrap his bandages. Working on a car when the fuel tank exploded, Mr. Pokorny received third-degree burns on about 42 percent of his body. Despite pain-killing drugs, Mr. Pokorny was in agonizing pain, which intensified when his bandages were changed. So doctors tried a new approach.

headline.main: Virtual Reality Finds a Real Place as a Medical Aid

docs.abstract: Virtual reality, interactive world created by computers, is finding a place in health care, particularly in pain management and helping people overcome phobias; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When I spotted my new patient in the psychiatry ward in the small hours of the morning, she was in the custody of two police officers and was naked except for a toga made of brightly flowered sheets. I instantly knew the diagnosis. When the patient informed me irritably that she was a famous European artist, I thought to myself, ''Right, and I'm Georgia O'Keeffe doing my night job.'' I completed a perfunctory history and physical, gave the orders for medication, and wrote up my summary: mania characterized by delusions of grandiosity, impaired judgment, sleeplessness, irritability. Then I went to bed.
docs.abstract: Dr Anna Fels article discusses pervasive problem in psychiatry of sorting out where 'reality' lies in no man's land between a patient's preconceptions and distortions of reality and those of the therapist; relates case in which she diagnosed woman claiming to be a famous artist--who was brought by police to psychiatry ward dressed only in a toga made of brightly flowered sheets--as psychotic and delusional, only to later discover that woman was who she claimed (Cases column) (M)

headline.main: A Doctor Redefines Traditional Cancer Care

docs.lead_paragraph: James Houpt was practicing magic tricks in front of his mirror recently, making coins disappear, when a reporter called to ask about his health. Mr. Houpt said he was fine. In fact, he had walked two-thirds of a mile that day. ''What's the big deal?'' he asked. Less than a week before, Mr. Houpt, a 51-year-old cab driver and magician, lay on an operating table at the veterans hospital in Pittsburgh having coronary artery bypass surgery -- and chatting away, albeit groggily, with the surgeons working on his heart.

headline.main: Making Some Trauma of Heart Surgery Disappear

docs.abstract: Article describes coronary artery bypass surgery performed on James Houpt by doctors from University of Pittsburgh and VA HealthCare System, thought to be first in US in which patient had heart surgery without general anesthesia; photo (M)
